node.title: Australia's word of the the year is phonetically satisfying  — and very frustrating
node.alt: A woman walks past a tent with a sign reading "vaccination centre entry".
node.description:
Word of the year season is getting political as two dictionaries, and the voting public, choose "strollout" as definitive of 2021, writes Tiger Webb.

Word of the year season gets political as two dictionaries, and the voting public, choose ‘strollout’ as definitive of 2021.
node.content:
["Two Australian dictionaries \u2014 and, in one poll, the Australian public \u2014 have chosen strollout as their word of the year for 2021.", "A blend of rollout and stroll, the word refers to the \"perceived lack of speed\" in Australia's vaccine rollout over the past year.", "In a relatively expedited Zoom session, the Macquarie Dictionary's word of the year committee \u2014 including author Kim Scott, Sydney University linguistics professor Nick Enfield, and dictionary editors Alison Moore and Victoria Morgan \u2014 opted for strollout over the ubiquitous Delta.", "The committee also gave honourable mentions to menty b (a laconic Australian abbreviation of \"mental breakdown\") and last chance tourism (\"tourism to locations with endangered landscapes or geological features, or which are habitats for endangered species\").", "", "
'Strollout' refers to the \"perceived lack of speed\" in Australia's vaccine rollout over the past year.(ABC News: Patrick Rocca)
", "This is not the first time strollout has got a guernsey this word of the year season. On November 17, Canberra's Australian National Dictionary Centre\u00a0announced strollout as their pick for their word of the year, beating out fellow longlistees Clayton's lockdown, Fortress Australia, AUKUS, and net zero.", "Clearly strollout resonates: not only had the Macquarie committee already settled on strollout in a closed session eight days earlier, but strollout also topped the people's choice votes collected by that dictionary.", "
The voting public and ivory tower in agreement
", "This year the Macquarie team had, for the first time, a live graph of people's choice votes as they flooded in. Initially, Delta seemed like it might take the gong, going head to head with strollout before the latter took an \"overwhelming\" lead. No surprise, according to dictionary editor Victoria Morgan: \"That's about what I thought would happen.\"", "At the time of writing, third place was yet to be settled, with porch pirate (\"a person who steals parcels from your front door\") vying for bronze on the popular vote with menty b.", "The Macquarie has selected a committee's choice and a people's choice since starting word of the year competitions in 2006. But 2021 marks the first time the results of both have been released at the same time.", "In previous years, Morgan says, it was difficult to tell whether the committee picks coloured the popular vote. \"We don't know whether our choice influenced other people's choice,\" she explains. This isn't the first time the same word has been picked for both, though: that honour goes to 2016's captain's call.", "
What makes strollout a winner?
", "Aiding the appeal of strollout is the fact that this particular blend works phonetically. Unlike covidiot, the source words for strollout have compatible stress patterns; unlike maskhole, the source words have perfect rhyme; and unlike hangxiety, a 2019 Macquarie word of the year longlistee combining hangover and anxiety, strollout has a relatively euphonious consonant cluster \u2014 the word-initial /str/ found in stretch, strong, and so on.", "Because of this euphony (or perhaps its political utility), Australian Council of Trade Unions secretary Sally McManus was keen\u00a0to claim strollout as her own invention. Undoubtedly her use of it in May this year would have led to wider adoption, but she was not the first.", "", "
Sally McManus was keen to claim strollout as her own invention.(ABC)
", "On March 3, a Canadian politician used the \"strollout, not a rollout\" line to criticise\u00a0that country's vaccine schedule. On April 14th, it was used in The Weekly with Charlie Pickering. On April 20, one of McManus's followers\u00a0urged her to apply the word\u00a0to the Australian context.", "Prior to all of this, strollout was used as a term for a\u00a0particularly glamorous genre of walking, and as a hashtag for fans of\u00a0F1 driver Alan Stroll.", "Not everyone was convinced. Breakfast television hosts in particular\u00a0were shocked\u00a0the ANDC had picked strollout; they claimed never to have heard of it, and queried whether it was deserving of the top spot. This is a risky critique, relying as it does on the assumption that you are more informed about language than the average lexicographer.", "A broader point that Kochie might ponder: what good would a dictionary be, if it only contained words you already knew?", "
Dictionary debates get heated, fast
", "It doesn't take much for dictionary definitions to become hotly contested: given the recent fracas\u00a0over ABC use of the phrase bungled vaccine rollout, it's unlikely strollout's triple crown will please many in Canberra.", "Adding fuel to the fire, it's usual for those unfamiliar with lexicographic practice to view \u2014 mistakenly, in many cases \u2014 the inclusion of words in dictionaries as some kind of endorsement from their compilers.", "At times, this tension has seemed a lot like government censorship: in 1977, the Commissioner for Community Relations Al Grassby demanded the Australian Pocket Oxford be pulped for including pejoratives dago and wop. A Canberra Times editorial\u00a0was suitably scathing, noting the Bible wasn't particularly kind on Romans either.", "In the 1950s, police raided the Karachi offices of the Oxford University Press, furious at the Concise Oxford's treatment of Pakistan as a state \"in India\". The press eventually apologised for its outdated and insensitive definition, but not before hundreds of copies were seized from schools and offices \u2014 including the sole copy in the press's Karachi office, which belonged to its typist.", "
Dictionaries and their limits
", "Even dictionary makers admit the works have their limits. Macquarie editor Victoria Morgan says references are useful, but aren't the be-all and end-all on political or legal stoushes. \"As the entries go into the dictionary they reflect common usage at that time,\" Morgan says, \"but entries could have gone in 30 years ago and may need to be updated.\"", "For her part, Morgan feels usage is already vindicating strollout, having seen the first indications of more general senses relating to government initiatives that aren't to do with vaccination. \"I wouldn't be surprised,\" she laughs.", "In pure lexicographer fashion, Morgan rushes to say she needs more data \u2014 perhaps the word is having a strollout of its own."]
